variants.overall_conclusion: The disease-associated mutation was studied in a cell phenotype rescue assay, which effectively models the disease pathogenesis. The assay used both wild-type and loss-of-function controls, was performed in triplicate, and has been broadly accepted historically. Additionally, a known pathogenic variant was used as a positive control. The statistical analysis of the data yielded an OddsPath greater than 18.7, indicating very strong evidence that this mutation is pathogenic.

The benign variant was studied in a protein interaction assay, which effectively models the disease pathogenesis. The assay used both wild-type and known gain-of-function controls, was performed in triplicate, and has been broadly accepted historically. Additionally, a known benign variant was used as a negative control. The statistical analysis of the data yielded an OddsPath less than 1/18.7, indicating very strong evidence that this variant is benign.
